chapter.title: The book layout manager

caption.para: The &ns;::w::booklayoutmanager extends the page layout manager by creating a horizontal strip of "tabs" above the paged container, containing one tab for each page. Clicking on a page's tab automatically opens the tab's page.

chapter.para: The following example is a modified version of pagelayoutmanager that uses the book layout manager. The code that creates a button to make each page visible gets removed. The book layout manager does that:

The book layout manager has a slightly different process for creating new pages. Both the page layout manager and the book layout manager have append() and insert() methods. &ns;::w::pagelayoutmanager's append() and insert() methods return a &factory; that directly creates display elements, with each display element becoming a new page. &ns;::w::booklayoutmanager's append() and insert() methods return a meta-factory object.

section.title: The book page factory
section.para: &ns;::w::booklayoutmanager's append and insert methods return an &ns;::w::bookpagefactory which is an intermediate object, and not a factory itself. Each call to &ns;::w::bookpagefactory's add() method creates a new page. add() takes a closure, or a callable object, as a parameter parameter.

There are two overloaded versions of add(). The first version takes a &ns;::w::text_param parameter that sets the new page's tab as a short text string. Its second parameter is a callable object or a closure that creates the new page. The second version takes only the callable object, or a closure, but the closure's parameters are two factories. The extra factory is for creating the new page's tab. Instead of a text string, the tab can be any non-focusable display element. The second version of add()'s parameters are a factory for creating the display element for the new page's tab, and a factory for creating the new display element for the new page (same parameter as the first version of add()).

For either version of add(), the closure must create exactly one display element using each one of its factory parmeters. For the second version of add() the closure may create the two display elements in either order.
Another optional parameter to add() is a keyboard &ns;::w::shortcut for opening the corresponding page.

section.title: The on_opened callback
section.para: on_opened() installs a &callback; that gets executed whenever the book layout manager makes a new page visible. The callback's &ns;::w::book_status_info_t parameter provides additional information: which page was opened and why.

section.title: An appdata example
section.para:
booklayoutmanager.C gives another example of using appdata.
booklayoutmanager.C takes the first &ns;::w::input_field on each page, and puts it into the appdata of each page's &ns;::w::container element.

The on_opened callback only needs to fetch the opened page's element. get_page() returns the &ns;::w::element base class references. The callback grabs the &ns;::w::input_field from the appdata, and put keyboard input focus into the input field every time one of the pages gets opened.

As explained in , parent containers hold internal references to all objects in the container, and in this manner booklayoutmanager.C also does the same itself, storing a reference to an &ns;::w::input_field in its parent container that comprises a page in the book.

note.para: The requirements explained in do not apply here. booklayoutmanager.C's on_opened callback does not capture any references, and only uses its parameters to retrieve the newly-opened page.

The reference stored in each container's appdata is not associated with any callback. It's just an ordinary reference pointer for an object. The reference pointer to a child object gets stored in each parent, like &appshort; normally does; and once the parent container gets removed, its references to its child display elements also get removed.
Only storing a reference to a parent display element, in its child's appdata, creates a circular reference because of the internal reference from the container to each child display elements.
